intro: Astragalus nuttallianus var. zapatanus, commonly known as Zapatanus milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a perennial herb characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, compound leaves. The plant produces yellow to orange flowers in late spring, which are clustered in umbels. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in sandy or gravelly soils. Botanically, it belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is known for its ability to fix nitrogen in the soil.
